POLICE PROTECTION FOR
STUDENTS TAKING THEIR
EXAMINATIONS


2.37 p.m.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Education (Mr Lee Khoon Choy): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move the following motion*,
*The motion also stood in the names of the Minister for Education, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister.


    That this House condemns the actions of the picketers in obstructing, intimidating, or otherwise forcefully preventing students from taking their examinations, and in response to an appeal from parents of students who wish to take these examinations that they and their children should be afforded Police protection, hereby resolves that this House supports any action by the Police to protect students wishing to take their examinations to ensure that they are not intimidated or injured, and that the students and their parents who accompany them are given free passage and access into and out of all examination halls.

Mr Speaker, Sir, you will recollect that last Thursday, the House condemned the illegal action of hooligans who tried to prevent me from attending the Assembly. However, as representatives of the people, we should be equally concerned for the safety of hundreds of parents and their children who are still being forcibly prevented from entering the examination rooms to take their examinations.

Column: 1128



    On Thursday last, with your kind permission, Sir, I read out a joint petition from a large number of parents urging me to bring to the attention of this House the fact that they would like police protection extended to parents and students, so that their safety could be ensured in the exercise of their right and freedom to take the Government examinations.

    The Government has so far refrained from using the police in order, to avoid a clash between the innocent and misguided students and the police, which is what the sinister men who are manipulating these children really want. The behind-the-scenes organisers of this boycott are working to bring about a clash between parents and picketing school children -

    An hon. Member: You are!

    Mr Lee Khoon Choy: - in the hope of sparking off violent emotions. If a clash should in fact occur, these evil men could then accuse the Government of using the Police Force against innocent students and they could then mount an anti-Government campaign to overthrow the Government.

    I had, Sir, on several occasions explained these sinister motives to representatives of parents who came to request for police protection following the intimidatory and rough tactics used by the picketers last week. But the intimidatory methods and force used by pickets during the past week have become so intense that the parents have decided to send in a joint petition urging me to get this House to sanction the use of police to protect them.

    Sir, before I proceed any further, I would like to emphasise the word "protection". What the parents and students are asking for is police protection and not police suppression, as the Barisan Sosialis had eerily and deliberately twisted and distorted in the Press statement which appeared in the Press on 1st December. Let us see how the Barisan Sosialis had twisted the meaning of this

Column: 1129

motion to incite the feelings of the people against the Government. This is an extract of the Press statement:

    'Now, the People's Action Party is in a hurry to use the police to suppress the growing tide of discontent and the Legislative Assembly cannot be responsible for the inability and evil acts of the P.A.P. Government. The Barisan Sosialis is strongly against any attempt to use the police force with reason to deal with students. We have seen enough of the violent acts of the Lim Yew Hock Government against the students.'

    This was an extract of the statement. Since Thursday last, there has been a deliberate attempt by the sinister men behind the scenes to whip up a feeling of hatred and hostility against the Government, not only among parents, but also among people in densely populated areas. Inflammatory slogans which were entirely unfounded, such as, "Special Agents Beat up Students" and "Students' Blood Does Not Flow In Vain" were painted in red on street walls, cinemas, lamp-posts and other strategica1ly glaring spots, with a view to inciting the feelings of the people against the Government.

    Sir, during the weekend, with the cooperation of the diligent staff of the Ministry of Education, we have made a thorough check of the actual number of students who have taken examinations and those that have not taken. We have facts, figures and names to prove that of the 3,171 candidates, only 927 have not taken their examinations. Of these 927, we have good reason to believe that many would have sat for the examinations, but for the intimidatory methods used by picketers. With the kind co-operation of the postal authorities, we have sent out urgent letters, signed personally by the Minister for Education, to parents of the 927 candidates, appealing to them to bring their children to sit for the supplementary examinations which began this morning.

    This morning, Sir, 240 candidates who were prevented last week from taking their examinations by pickets have turned up for the supplementary examinations.

Column: 1130

A large number of parents rang up the Ministry to complain again that their children were still prevented from entering the examination rooms. There are still human chains outside the examination centres. Similar methods of intimidation are being used by the pickets. The parents have emphasised in their petition to me that in a democratic country like ours, the people should have the democratic right and freedom to sit for an examination. When such freedom and rights are interfered with by uninvited intimidation and force, it is the duty of the Government to see that such rights are upheld and the parents protected.

    What the parents are asking for, Sir, is police protection and not police suppression, as twisted by the Barisan Sosialis. If the picketers had from the beginning adopted peaceful methods of persuasion instead of the type of hooliganism as we have witnessed, then this motion would not have been necessary.

    According to Press reports, Sir, the picketers claim that 2,000 so-called parents attended a meeting at the Chinese High School yesterday and passed certain resolutions supporting the picketers. One of the resolutions sounds rather mysterious and no doubt it was coined in such terms as to mislead the people. It reads: "Determined to oppose using of military and police against students who use peaceful persuasion to picket and determined to request the Government to withdraw its motion on December the 4th to condemn the picketers."

    Sir, you will have seen the Straits Times of 30th November with a picture on the front page, and everybody in the city knows whether this is peaceful persuasion or this is intimidation.

    Sir, who are these so-called parents? So far, according to official figures, only 927 candidates have not taken examinations last week, and of these, 240 have sat for the supplementary examinations this morning, leaving barely 600 candidates who have not taken examinations. Of these 600, many have rung up to say

Column: 1131

that they could not get into examination rooms. Even taking for granted that there are 600 picketers, surely 600 picketers cannot have 2,000 parents. We challenge the picketers to publish the names of these so-called parents and the names of their children who they claim are candidates of the Government Secondary IV examinations.

    On our side, Sir, we are prepared and ready to publish the names of candidates who have taken the examinations and those who have not taken them so that the public will not be confused and misled into believing that the action of the picketers has got the support of the majority of parents.

    Sir, the resolution which I have just mentioned - that is the slogan by the so-called parents at the Chinese High School - gave the impression that the Government had used the military and the police against innocent students. This, I say, is most mischievous. The whole city knows and, in fact, in many cases the Government has been blamed for not doing its duty to maintain law and order. Nobody, except in the imagination of the agitators, has seen any military truck or any police in action against the students during the last week.

    Sir, we have stressed over and over again that it is not the intention of the Government to use the Police Force against students. As long as the real non-student organisers of this dangerous campaign believe that there are Members of this House ready to condone this picketing, and, what is more important, ready to exploit the strong emotions that could be aroused as a result of clashes between children and police, these non-student organisers will egg the picketers on to more desperate acts of provocation.

    Sir, if the elected representatives of this House - both Government and Opposition - make it quite clear that they are on the side of law and order, that no Assemblyman will be prepared to exploit a situation arising when the police give such assistance as may be necessary to parents and students in the exercise of their lawful rights, then I

Column: 1132

am certain that the non-student organisers of this picketing and the picketers themselves will not embark on acts of recklessness. They will not do so because they will then know that behind the lawful exercise of police authority there is, the sanction of not only parents and students but also of the elected representatives of the people without regard to party conflicts and bribery. For in this case, we are not dealing with an educational issue but with an explosive situation which, if badly handled, could plunge this whole city into violence and disorder. In this case, the organisers of this boycott are working to bring about a clash between the police and picketing school children in the hope of sparking off violent emotions. But there is a clear indication, Sir, that if and when police protection has to be enforced it would have behind it the backing of the public, students, parents and all our Assemblymen, then the organisers of this dangerous and cowardly campaign would know that if they do anything foolish they would have the full force of public opinion at every level against them and these agitators would themselves have to face the anger of the people and take the full consequences.

    In view of this, Sir, we ask every Member of this House to make it clear that where police authority is lawfully and justly used as in this case, it would have the endorsement o, all Members of this House.

    Sir, I beg to move.

    Question proposed.

2.55 p.m.

    Mr A. P. Rajah (Farrer Park): Mr Speaker, Sir, some three or four days ago, I had occasion to speak in this House about matters appertaining to the present motion before the House.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I for one cannot understand how the problem of education and any disagreement in an educational system which the State has arrived at after due and proper consultations with persons who are able to advise the Government on these matters, should have now turned out

Column: 1133

into the issue which it has. -If the issue before the country is whether Chinese students should be allowed to take the Secondary IV examination, I personally am not competent to speak on that. But in such matters on which I am not competent to speak, naturally I am guided by persons who are competent to speak on such matters and, in my view, the persons who are competent to speak on these matters are the educational experts in the Chinese educational field. As far as I could understand from the Government, these people have been consulted and it was agreed that the Secondary IV examination was a good thing for Chinese education and Chinese culture. Apparently, that was the situation two or three months ago, but since then things have taken a different turn.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I was speaking to a friend of mine who is also interested in education. He is not interested in the Chinese education stream but he is interested in the English education stream. He is attached to the University. He has some experience of education and children and how children react to examinations. He told me that if a vote was taken amongst the children as to whether they should get promotions without sitting for examinations, more than fifty per cent of them would vote for promotions without sitting for examinations. That would be the position if students were asked to express their views on it on a democratic basis.

    But let us not overplay this democratic basis, Mr Speaker, Sir,In my own home, I would like to think that I treat my children fairly and well, and that the way I treat them is not the way my grandfather treated my father or my father treated me. But then there comes a point of time when in every home, as in every State, authority must be applied and the young children of the country must be told where they get off - if I may use a colloquialism. And if in the view of a parent - and who knows better what the interest of the child is than the parent? - the child is going off the track, it is up to the

Column: 1134

father and the mother to pull him up and tell him where he has got off the track. And if he gets difficult about it, then the solution is to put him across the lap and to administer a couple of good smacks where it will hurt most! That is how I would deal with the situation in my own home. The State, Mr Speaker, Sir, is merely a translation of the various homes into one. Now if the children are objecting to this examination when all the educational authorities are agreed that it is a good thing for Chinese education, I say that the children who are acting as picketers should be dealt with in an appropriate manner, first of all by the parents of those children. Therefore, Mr Speaker, Sir, however much these students disagree with the Secondary IV examination, I do not think it is their business to go and picket and prevent others, particularly, when from the results that we have seen, according to the statement of the Minister for Education, about two-thirds of them have attended these examinations. On a democratic basis where the minority accepts the will of the majority, I suggest that the picketers should silently take up their tents and vanish. If one is talking about democracy, that is the way the pickets should behave. So that from that point of view, I am entirely with the 66 per cent of the students who are going into these examinations, and I appeal to the picketers no to prevent the others from, taking their examinations. If they have any legitimate objections to the Secondary IV examinations, they have their channels through which to make representations. If those representations are logical, to the effect that the Chinese language and Chinese culture are going to be destroyed, that naturally any government must take heed and make the necessary adjustments. But in the meantime, Mr Speaker, Sir, we have a problem, that is, children who wish to take these examinations are being prevented from doing so. The duty of the Government - as the parents have rightly pointed out - in the democratic system, when the people want to exercise their lawful rights and somebody else is trying to prevent them from exercising these rights - is to come to their rescue.

Column: 1135



    Therefore, Mr Speaker, Sir, I am wholeheartedly in support of the motion, but I think the terms of the motion are such that it is liable to give some misunderstanding to people outside. When the motion about the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Education came before the House, where it was a question of violation of the rights of a Member of this Assembly, I thought it was for the Assembly to direct the police to take the necessary action. In this instance, where the rights of a citizen are being violated, it is the duty of the State to protect that citizen and to see that his civil rights are not being violated. Therefore, the responsibility of protecting such a citizen falls fairly and squarely on the shoulders of the Government. But as a responsible legislature which happens to be sitting at the moment when Government is faced with a problem, and if the Government comes to this House for an expression of its opinion on the problem before it, then, of course, the Government is entitled to get a fair answer from the House. Therefore. Mr Speaker. Sir, I wish to move an amendment to the latter part of the motion. I have here a typewritten copy. Mr Speaker, Sir. The amendment will be,

    To delete the words "supports any action by" in lines 6 and 7 of the motion, and insert therefor the words, "approves of any action according to law by the Government through".

If I may repeat it again, Mr Speaker, Sir,

    To delete the words "supports any action by" in lines 6 and 7, and insert therefor the words. "approves of any action according to law by the Government through".

    Amendment handed in.

    Mr Speaker: The amendment is in order.

    Mr Rajah: Sir, I will not be very long. I think I have made my point. The amendment, Sir, is moved in order to clear certain doubts.

    As the motion stands, it says "... hereby resolves that this House supports any action by the Police ..." Now that might give room for doubt, although the Government will naturally say that "any action by the Police" there means

Column: 1136

any lawful action. But it could mean that any action could be taken by the police, and if something turns out to be unlawful, they might come back to the House and say, "Well, you have already agreed to this. Therefore, pass legislation which will idemnify." We do not want all that. I think what the Government can do and should do is to act according to law in respect of persons acting not in accordance with the law. And it is with that intent and purpose, Sir, that this amendment is moved.

    Mr Speaker: The Original Question was,

    'That this House condemns the actions of the picketers in obstructing, intimidating, or otherwise forcefully preventing students from taking their examinations, and in response to an appeal from parents of students who wish to take these examinations that they and their children should be afforded Police protection, hereby resolves that this House supports any action by the Police to protect students wishing to take their examinations to ensure that they are not intimidated or injured, and that the students and their parents who accompany them are given free passage and access into and out of all examination halls."

    Since which an amendment has been proposed.

    In lines 6 and 7, to leave out the words "supports any action by", and there to insert "approves of any action according to law by the Government through".

    The Question is, "That the words proposed to be left out, be left out."

    Perhaps it might be for the convenience of hon. Members if I suggest that in the debate that is to follow, Members debate both the original motion and the amendment, so that at the end of the debate - it means, of course, that each Member will be allowed one speech, and not more than one speech, except the proposer of the substantive motion who will have the right to reply - I will put the Question on the amendment, and then on the original motion, as amended, as the case may be. That is for the convenience of hon. Members. No dissenting voice.

    Mr Lee Khoon Choy: Sir, the Government accepts the amendment.

    Mr Speaker: Well, that is an indication for hon. Members.

Column: 1137



3.06 p.m.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh (Queenstown): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Parliamentary Secretary has given his own grim picture of so-called sinister men - but sinister men of the P.A.P.'s own making, own make-believe, so that they can keep on building and maintaining that artificial atmosphere of tension and suspense. This will fit into their scheme of things, Sir, as I will endeavour to explain. The Parliamentary Secretary also talked of the hooliganism of the students. We, on our part, Sir, never believe that the students can ever be hooligans. Hooliganism is only present in those mysterious people who wear drainpipe trousers, who throw stones, bulbs and glasses at the students, and generally attack the students in every way.

    Sir, education issues are always emotional issues. And emotional issues bring out undesirable features which, in a debate of this nature, we want to avoid. For this reason alone, we would have preferred the motion before the House not be debated now. There would be cries of chauvinism from people who do not understand the Chinese education problem. Even the Deputy Prime Minister himself, Sir, -

    Mr Lee Khoon Choy: Do you understand?

    Mr Speaker: Order.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: - said the other day that Nanyang University is evidence of Chinese chauvinism. So we see how even the so-called enlightened -

    The Deputy Prime Minister (Dr Toh Chin Chye): On a point of order, Sir.

    Mr Speaker: Point of order.

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: I want to know when he quoted me definitely in which and in what context I said those very words.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: I cannot quote you the exact context, Sir, but it was said in this very Assembly only a few days ago.

Column: 1138



    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): He was away!

    Mr Lee Khoon Choy: Don't bluff!

    Mr Speaker: Order.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: Let him look at the Hansard, and the exact truth will be revealed.

    As I say, even a Chairman of a political Party who once upon a time preached equal treatment for the four streams of education can make blunders like this. It is no wonder that people outside are becoming more and more confused. Sir, the motion before the House is not just to get the Assembly to endorse the rule of law and order. That is not necessary. We all want law and order.

    The Prime Minister: That is what we want to know.

    Mr Speaker: Order.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: We, in the Barisan Sosialis, all abide by the Queensberry rules of parliamentary democracy in spite of the Siamese boxing indulged in by the P.A.P.

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: Judo!

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: Sir, this motion has, however, been introduced with sinister motives. There were already insinuations and innuendoes of pro-Communist elements inside and outside the Assembly. There were suggestions that the Barisan Sosialis was obstructive and did not allow the Assembly to discuss important matters of State. We have seen, Sir, how surprise motions, one after another, were introduced in the midst of this merger debate, and it is not unexpected therefore that we have this motion before the House. The P.A.P. hopes that such diversion will draw the attention of the people away from the ugly revelations of their sell-out merger. The P.A.P. is desperately trying to divert public attention from the merger debate in which -

    The Prime Minister: Sir, on a point of order. After you have ruled that a Member should avoid tedious repetition, if I may quote the exact words,

Column: 1139

Sir, of Standing Order 54 to which you drew the attention of the House:

    'The Speaker or the Chairman, after having drawn attention to the conduct of a Member, who persists in irrelevance, or tedious repetition either of his own arguments or of the arguments used by other Members in debate, may direct him to discontinue his speech.'

    I have heard all this, Sir, even though it was in some other debate. Could we be spared?

    Mr Speaker: Order. I suppose there is a little repetition. A little repetition is inevitable since this motion and the merger motion overlap. I suppose a little repetition is unavoidable. It is only when it becomes tedious that the Speaker will have to intervene. Perhaps the Member for Queenstown will bear that in mind.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: Sir, this only proves my point, namely, that they are trying to distract public attention from the merger issue. We are quite used to tricks like this. We were in the P.A.P. at one time, so we know -

    An hon. Member: Traitors!

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: - what tricks are up their sleeves.

    Sir, what are the real motives be, hind this sudden move? As I said, these motives are all sinister. As you know, Sir, there is a deliberate attempt on the part of the P.A.P. to smear all those who do not agree with them as Communists and pro-Communists. And this motion is meant to link the Barisan Sosialis with the students' strike and paint everything as Communist inspired. Thus, Sir, just because the students stick posters on Chinese-owned buses, and as Mr Fong Swee Suan (you will remember the other day, Sir) is the adviser to the Singapore Bus Workers' Union -

    The Minister for Culture (Mr S. Rajaratnam): He is a Barisan man.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: - the adviser to that union, so, according to the P.A.P., Mr Fong must be responsible for those posters on the buses! Such dangerous and illogical reasoning of the P.A.P. shows how completely off the track they have gone. Sir, many will know that posters have also been stuck

Column: 1140

on the S.T.C. buses and trolleys. Mr Devan Nair is adviser to the S.T.C. Employees' Union. If we were to accept the P.A.P.'s logic, would we not have to blame Mr Devan Nair for the students' dissatisfaction? Again, Sir, the Member for Anson is -

    Mr David Marshall (Anson): He is here to defend himself!

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: - is the legal adviser to the Public Daily-Rated Employees Union Federation. On the same logic, are we to blame the Member for Anson for the recent strike -

    The Prime Minister: Nobody did, you know. That is the point.

    Mr Speaker: Order.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: Sir, year after year, millions of dollars - money which has been taken from the people - has been spent on the Special Branch. For what? So that the Special Branch can misrepresent all expression of genuine grievances of the people as Communist-inspired? For getting intelligence like that concerning Tommy Koh? I will come to the Special Branch again. Sir.

    Mr Speaker: Order. I hope we are not going to embark on a debate on the Special Branch, because I will not allow it.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: No, Sir. I just want to bring out the relevant points about the Special Branch in this particular motion.
